After being organized and briefed on the mission by Maj. Gen Jaleel (then Lt.), the patrol was addressed by Maj. Gen (Ret.) Mohamed Zahir (then Major) who was the leading Commander at the NSS HQ at the time. The patrol formed up on the half wall fronting the street then with Maj. Gen Jaleel, the commander at the lead of the patrol, ran out through the gate and along Ameeru Ahmed magu towards Huravee Building. Due to reasons unknown only 9 member were able to run out the gate with 2 members remaining inside. As the attackers noticed the patrol running out of the HQ they intensified the fire towards them and additionally a member of the patrol slipped and was unable to use his weapon to return fire which resulted in 3 member of the patrol being killed under fire. The remaining 6 members completed their mission and returned inside the base through the same gate. The mission is undoubtedly the most daring in the modern military history of the country. The soldiers who volunteered for the mission undertook it with full knowledge that they were venturing out a HQ which was under siege and into the hail of bullets from the attackers. And Maj. Gen Jaleel holds a legendary status in the MNDF as the commander who led this mission. ==Family== Maj. General Jaleel is married to Mrs. Jazeela Ibrahim. He has 5 children, with 1 from the current marriage and 4 from previous marriages. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = [[Mohamed Zahir]]|title =Chief of Defence Force (Maldives)| years = 2008–present| after = Incumbent}} {{s-end}} {{Persondata | NAME = Jaleel, Moosa Ali | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 26 June 1960 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jaleel, Moosa Ali}} [[Category:Maldivian military personnel]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:People from Malé]]

{{Infobox military person | name = Major General Moosa Ali Jaleel | image=[[File:Jaleel1.jpg|210px|Moosa Ali Jaleel]] | imagesize =210px | birth_date= {{Birth date and age|1960|06|26}} | death_date= | birth_place= | death_place= | placeofburial= | caption= Maj. Gen Jaleel (then Brig.) at the Pacific Armies Management Seminar in Fiji | nickname= Jaleel / CO | allegiance={{flag|Maldives}} | branch=[[Maldives National Defence Force]] | serviceyears= | rank= [[Major General]] | commands=Chief of Defence Force
Vice Chief of Defence Force
Commanding General - Rapid Reaction Force
Director General - Coast Guard
Commanding Officer - Quick Reaction Force I & II & III
Commanding Officer - Special Protection Group
Commanding Officer - Maldives National Cadet Corps | unit= | battles=[[1988 Maldives Coup]] | awards=Medal for Exceptional Bravery (Huravee Ran Medal)
[[Distinguished Service Medal]]
Presidential Medal
3 November Medal
MNDF Service Medal
Dedicated Service Medal
Medal of Good Conduct
[[Centenary Medal]]
[[Long Service Medal]]
[[Purple Heart Medal]] (Jihaadhuge Raiy Medal) | laterwork= }} [[Major General]] '''Moosa Ali Jaleel''' RM HRM MSc ndc [[psc]] is the current '''Chief of Defence Force''' of the [[Maldives]] and most senior military officer in the country.http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v1//uploads/op_chart/op_chart.html He is frequently cited as the most highly trained and capable military officer in the country. People who are knowledgeable about [[1988 Maldives Coup|the November 3rd 1988 incident]] and Maj. General Jaleel's bravery and dedicated action that day hold him in the highest regard and respect.{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-V0G78k6jgg|title= Youtube: Moosa Jaleel 3 November Interview|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=}}http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v3/?page_id=17 Maj. General Moosa Jaleel was appointed to the post of '''Chief of Defence Force''' on the 18th November 2008 by the President HE [[Mohamed Nasheed]].http://www.idsa.in/TWIR/11_3_2008_Maldives ==Biography== Maj. General Jaleel was born on 26 June 1960 in [[Malé]], Maldives. He completed his secondary schooling at [[Majeediyya School]]. ===Military Career and Training=== Maj. General Jaleel has the distinction of having been trained at various UK, US and Indian Military Institutes: ; Singapore * [[Officer Cadet School (Singapore)|Officer Cadet School]], [[SAFTI Military Institute|Singapore Armed Forces Training Institute]] (SAFTI) ;United States * [[United States Army Infantry School]], [[Fort Benning]] (Infantry Officer Basic Course / Infantry Officer Advance Course) * Defense Resources Management Institute at [[Naval Postgraduate School]], Monterey California * [[Asia Pacific Center for Security Studies]] (APCSS), Hawaii * [[Near East South Asia Center for Strategic Studies]], Washington DC ;United Kingdom * [[Royal Marines]] Commando School, Lympstone ([[All Arms Commando Course]]) ;India * [[Defence Services Staff College]], Wellington * [[National Defence College]], New Delhi In addition, Maj. General Jaleel holds a Master of Philosophy, M.Phil. and a Master of Science Degree in Defence and Strategic Studies, M.Sc from the [[University of Madras]] India. He also attends the Pacific Armies Management Seminar (PAMS) organized by the [[United States Pacific Command]]. He has commanded all front line infantry units in the MNDF including the '''Rapid Reaction Force''' (RRF), '''Quick Reaction Force III''' (QRF 3), '''Quick Reaction Force I''' (QRF I), '''Special Protection Group''' (SPG) and has also served as the Director General of [[Maldivian Coast Guard]]. He was the first Maldivian to initiate infantry oriented training in Maldives. He trained a large amount MNDF personnel and also served as the Commanding Officer of the Maldives National Cadet Corp. He enjoys a tremendous amount of public as well as soldiers support and is expected to re-organize and restructure the MNDF as a mission oriented armed force. His experience in various MNDF Units as well as the broad knowledge and wide range of skills makes him a great asset to MNDF and the Maldives. Among his distinctions he's the first Maldivian to complete Officer Cadet training and the only Maldivian graduate of Singapore Armed Forces Officer Cadet School. The only Maldivian to undertake the UK [[Royal Marines]] [[All Arms Commando Course]], as such he's entitled to wear the Commando badge of UK [[Royal Marines]] which is one of the world's most elite fighting forces. Furthermore he's the first Maldivian to accomplish Defence College / War College studies, which is the highest level of military studies attainable. ===Military Decorations=== Maj. General Jaleel is one of the most highly decorated officers, with 10 Service Medals and 9 Service Ribbons for his exemplary leadership and distinguished service in the defence force.{{cite web|url=http://www.miadhu.com/2010/11/local-news/chief-of-defence-force-major-general-moosa-ali-jaleel-awarded-purple-heart-and-long-service-meda|title= Miadhu News (Maldives)|author=|date=2010-11-04|publisher=|accessdate=2010-12-17}} ; Service Medal decorations[ http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v3/?page_id=25 * The Medal for Exceptional Bravery (Huravee Ran Medal) * The Distinguished Service Medal * The Presidential Medal * The 3 November Medal * The MNDF Service Medal * The Dedicated Service Medal * The Medal of Good Conduct * The Centenary Medal * The Long Service Medal * The Purple Heart Medal (Jihaadhuge Raiy Medal) ; Service Ribbon decorations * Presidential Ribbon * Long Service Ribbon * Dedicated Service Ribbon * MNDF Ribbon * Achievement Ribbon (Twice) * Special Service Ribbon * Good Conduct Ribbon (Twice) ===November 3rd 1988 attack=== {{see also|1988 Maldives Coup}} Maj. General Jaleel played a pivotal role in organizing and leading the defence of the NSS HQ during the attack. His military training and knowledge proved to be most valuable to the commanders at the NSS HQ. He received a bullet/shrapnel injury to his leg early on while retaliating to the attacker at the North-East corner of the Bandaara Koshi where the fighting was most intense but even with this injury he continued performing throughout the incident remarkably. His bravery and dedication are most notable as the Commander of the Recce patrol. The Recce patrol was an effort to venture of the NSS HQ which was under siege to retaliate and gather knowledge of the attacker. The first attempt was made to leave the HQ in buses with a tractor leading the way, this effort was aborted after the gate could not be opened as it was jammed due to damage. The second attempt was made through the Defence Ministry gate (then Police HQ gate) on foot. 11 soldiers with task force training volunteered for this mission. After being organized and briefed on the mission by Maj. Gen Jaleel (then Lt.), the patrol was addressed by Maj. Gen (Ret.) Mohamed Zahir (then Major) who was the leading Commander at the NSS HQ at the time. The patrol formed up on the half wall fronting the street then with Maj. Gen Jaleel, the commander at the lead of the patrol, ran out through the gate and along Ameeru Ahmed magu towards Huravee Building. Due to reasons unknown only 9 member were able to run out the gate with 2 members remaining inside. As the attackers noticed the patrol running out of the HQ they intensified the fire towards them and additionally a member of the patrol slipped and was unable to use his weapon to return fire which resulted in 3 member of the patrol being killed under fire. The remaining 6 members completed their mission and returned inside the base through the same gate. The mission is undoubtedly the most daring in the modern military history of the country. The soldiers who volunteered for the mission undertook it with full knowledge that they were venturing out a HQ which was under siege and into the hail of bullets from the attackers. And Maj. Gen Jaleel holds a legendary status in the MNDF as the commander who led this mission. ==Family== Maj. General Jaleel is married to Mrs. Jazeela Ibrahim. He has 5 children, with 1 from the current marriage and 4 from previous marriages. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = [[Mohamed Zahir]]|title =Chief of Defence Force (Maldives)| years = 2008–present| after = Incumbent}} {{s-end}} {{Persondata | NAME = Jaleel, Moosa Ali | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 26 June 1960 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jaleel, Moosa Ali}} [[Category:Maldivian military personnel]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:People from Malé]]

General Jaleel holds a Master of Philosophy, M.Phil. and a Master of Science Degree in Defence and Strategic Studies, M.Sc from the [[University of Madras]] India. He also attends the Pacific Armies Management Seminar (PAMS) organized by the [[United States Pacific Command]]. He has commanded all front line infantry units in the MNDF including the '''Rapid Reaction Force''' (RRF), '''Quick Reaction Force III''' (QRF 3), '''Quick Reaction Force I''' (QRF I), '''Special Protection Group''' (SPG) and has also served as the Director General of [[Maldivian Coast Guard]]. He was the first Maldivian to initiate infantry oriented training in Maldives. He trained a large amount MNDF personnel and also served as the Commanding Officer of the Maldives National Cadet Corp. He enjoys a tremendous amount of public as well as soldiers support and is expected to re-organize and restructure the MNDF as a mission oriented armed force. His experience in various MNDF Units as well as the broad knowledge and wide range of skills makes him a great asset to MNDF and the Maldives. Among his distinctions he's the first Maldivian to complete Officer Cadet training and the only Maldivian graduate of Singapore Armed Forces Officer Cadet School. The only Maldivian to undertake the UK [[Royal Marines]] [[All Arms Commando Course]], as such he's entitled to wear the Commando badge of UK [[Royal Marines]] which is one of the world's most elite fighting forces. Furthermore he's the first Maldivian to accomplish Defence College / War College studies, which is the highest level of military studies attainable. ===Military Decorations=== Maj. General Jaleel is one of the most highly decorated officers, with 10 Service Medals and 9 Service Ribbons for his exemplary leadership and distinguished service in the defence force.{{cite web|url=http://www.miadhu.com/2010/11/local-news/chief-of-defence-force-major-general-moosa-ali-jaleel-awarded-purple-heart-and-long-service-meda|title= Miadhu News (Maldives)|author=|date=2010-11-04|publisher=|accessdate=2010-12-17}} ; Service Medal decorations[http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v3/?page_id=25 ] * The Medal for Exceptional Bravery (Huravee Ran Medal) * The Distinguished Service Medal * The Presidential Medal * The 3 November Medal * The MNDF Service Medal * The Dedicated Service Medal * The Medal of Good Conduct * The Centenary Medal * The Long Service Medal * The Purple Heart Medal (Jihaadhuge Raiy Medal) ; Service Ribbon decorations * Presidential Ribbon * Long Service Ribbon * Dedicated Service Ribbon * MNDF Ribbon * Achievement Ribbon (Twice) * Special Service Ribbon * Good Conduct Ribbon (Twice) ===November 3rd 1988 attack=== {{see also|1988 Maldives Coup}} Maj. General Jaleel played a pivotal role in organizing and leading the defence of the NSS HQ during the attack. His military training and knowledge proved to be most valuable to the commanders at the NSS HQ. He received a bullet/shrapnel injury to his leg early on while retaliating to the attacker at the North-East corner of the Bandaara Koshi where the fighting was most intense but even with this injury he continued performing throughout the incident remarkably. His bravery and dedication are most notable as the Commander of the Recce patrol. The Recce patrol was an effort to venture of the NSS HQ which was under siege to retaliate and gather knowledge of the attacker. The first attempt was made to leave the HQ in buses with a tractor leading the way, this effort was aborted after the gate could not be opened as it was jammed due to damage. The second attempt was made through the Defence Ministry gate (then Police HQ gate) on foot. 11 soldiers with task force training volunteered for this mission. After being organized and briefed on the mission by Maj. Gen Jaleel (then Lt.), the patrol was addressed by Maj. Gen (Ret.) Mohamed Zahir (then Major) who was the leading Commander at the NSS HQ at the time. The patrol formed up on the half wall fronting the street then with Maj. Gen Jaleel, the commander at the lead of the patrol, ran out through the gate and along Ameeru Ahmed magu towards Huravee Building. Due to reasons unknown only 9 member were able to run out the gate with 2 members remaining inside. As the attackers noticed the patrol running out of the HQ they intensified the fire towards them and additionally a member of the patrol slipped and was unable to use his weapon to return fire which resulted in 3 member of the patrol being killed under fire. The remaining 6 members completed their mission and returned inside the base through the same gate. The mission is undoubtedly the most daring in the modern military history of the country. The soldiers who volunteered for the mission undertook it with full knowledge that they were venturing out a HQ which was under siege and into the hail of bullets from the attackers. And Maj. Gen Jaleel holds a legendary status in the MNDF as the commander who led this mission. ==Family== Maj. General Jaleel is married to Mrs. Jazeela Ibrahim. He has 5 children, with 1 from the current marriage and 4 from previous marriages. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = [[Mohamed Zahir]]|title =Chief of Defence Force (Maldives)| years = 2008–present| after = Incumbent}} {{s-end}} {{Persondata | NAME = Jaleel, Moosa Ali | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 26 June 1960 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jaleel, Moosa Ali}} [[Category:Maldivian military personnel]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:People from Malé]]

He was the first Maldivian to initiate infantry oriented training in Maldives. He trained a large amount MNDF personnel and also served as the Commanding Officer of the Maldives National Cadet Corp. He enjoys a tremendous amount of public as well as soldiers support and is expected to re-organize and restructure the MNDF as a mission oriented armed force. His experience in various MNDF Units as well as the broad knowledge and wide range of skills makes him a great asset to MNDF and the Maldives. Among his distinctions he's the first Maldivian to complete Officer Cadet training and the only Maldivian graduate of Singapore Armed Forces Officer Cadet School. The only Maldivian to undertake the UK [[Royal Marines]] [[All Arms Commando Course]], as such he's entitled to wear the Commando badge of UK [[Royal Marines]] which is one of the world's most elite fighting forces. Furthermore he's the first Maldivian to accomplish Defence College / War College studies, which is the highest level of military studies attainable. ===Military Decorations=== Maj. General Jaleel played a pivotal role in organizing and leading the defence of the NSS HQ during the attack. His military training and knowledge proved to be most valuable to the commanders at the NSS HQ. He received a bullet/shrapnel injury to his leg early on while retaliating to the attacker at the North-East corner of the Bandaara Koshi where the fighting was most intense but even with this injury he continued performing throughout the incident remarkably. His bravery and dedication are most notable as the Commander of the Recce patrol. The Recce patrol was an effort to venture of the NSS HQ which was under siege to retaliate and gather knowledge of the attacker. The first attempt was made to leave the HQ in buses with a tractor leading the way, this effort was aborted after the gate could not be opened as it was jammed due to damage. Mohamed Zahir (then Major) who was the leading Commander at the NSS HQ at the time. The patrol formed up on the half wall fronting the street then with Maj. {{Infobox military person | name = Major General Moosa Ali Jaleel | image=[[File:Jaleel1.jpg|210px|Moosa Ali Jaleel]] | imagesize =210px | birth_date= {{Birth date and age|1960|06|26}} | death_date= | birth_place= | death_place= | placeofburial= | caption= Maj. Gen Jaleel (then Brig.) at the Pacific Armies Management Seminar in Fiji | nickname= Jaleel / CO | allegiance={{flag|Maldives}} | branch=[[Maldives National Defence Force]] | serviceyears= | rank= [[Major General]] | commands=Chief of Defence Force
Vice Chief of Defence Force
Commanding General - Rapid Reaction Force
Director General - Coast Guard
Commanding Officer - Quick Reaction Force I & II & III
Commanding Officer - Special Protection Group
Commanding Officer - Maldives National Cadet Corps | unit= | battles=[[1988 Maldives Coup]] | awards=Medal for Exceptional Bravery (Huravee Ran Medal)
[[Distinguished Service Medal (Maldives)|Distinguished Service Medal]]
Presidential Medal
3 November Medal
MNDF Service Medal
Dedicated Service Medal
Medal of Good Conduct
[[Centenary Medal]]
[[Long Service Medal]]
[[Purple Heart Medal]] (Jihaadhuge Raiy Medal) | laterwork= }} [[Major General]] '''Moosa Ali Jaleel''' RM HRM MSc ndc [[psc]] was the former '''Chief of Defence Force''' of the [[Maldives]] and most senior military officer in the country.http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v1//uploads/op_chart/op_chart.html He is frequently cited as the most highly trained and capable military officer in the country. People who are knowledgeable about [[1988 Maldives Coup|the November 3rd 1988 incident]] and Maj. General Jaleel's bravery and dedicated action that day hold him in the highest regard and respect.{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-V0G78k6jgg|title= Youtube: Moosa Jaleel 3 November Interview|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=}}http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v3/?page_id=17 Maj. General Moosa Jaleel was appointed to the post of '''Chief of Defence Force''' on the 18th November 2008 by the President HE [[Mohamed Nasheed]].http://www.idsa.in/TWIR/11_3_2008_Maldives ==Biography== Maj. General Jaleel was born on 26 June 1960 in [[Malé]], Maldives. He completed his secondary schooling at [[Majeediyya School]]. ===Military Career and Training=== Maj. General Jaleel has the distinction of having been trained at various UK, US and Indian Military Institutes: ; Singapore * [[Officer Cadet School (Singapore)|Officer Cadet School]], [[SAFTI Military Institute|Singapore Armed Forces Training Institute]] (SAFTI) ;United States * [[United States Army Infantry School]], [[Fort Benning]] (Infantry Officer Basic Course / Infantry Officer Advance Course) * Defense Resources Management Institute at [[Naval Postgraduate School]], Monterey California * [[Asia Pacific Center for Security Studies]] (APCSS), Hawaii * [[Near East South Asia Center for Strategic Studies]], Washington DC ;United Kingdom * [[Royal Marines]] Commando School, Lympstone ([[All Arms Commando Course]]) ;India * [[Defence Services Staff College]], Wellington * [[National Defence College]], New Delhi In addition, Maj. General Jaleel holds a Master of Philosophy, M.Phil. and a Master of Science Degree in Defence and Strategic Studies, M.Sc from the [[University of Madras]] India. He also attends the Pacific Armies Management Seminar (PAMS) organized by the [[United States Pacific Command]]. He has commanded all front line infantry units in the MNDF including the '''Rapid Reaction Force''' (RRF), '''Quick Reaction Force III''' (QRF 3), '''Quick Reaction Force I''' (QRF I), '''Special Protection Group''' (SPG) and has also served as the Director General of [[Maldivian Coast Guard]]. He was the first Maldivian to initiate infantry oriented training in Maldives. He trained a large amount MNDF personnel and also served as the Commanding Officer of the Maldives National Cadet Corp. He enjoys a tremendous amount of public as well as soldiers support and is expected to re-organize and restructure the MNDF as a mission oriented armed force. His experience in various MNDF Units as well as the broad knowledge and wide range of skills makes him a great asset to MNDF and the Maldives. Among his distinctions he's the first Maldivian to complete Officer Cadet training and the only Maldivian graduate of Singapore Armed Forces Officer Cadet School. The only Maldivian to undertake the UK [[Royal Marines]] [[All Arms Commando Course]], as such he's entitled to wear the Commando badge of UK [[Royal Marines]] which is one of the world's most elite fighting forces. Furthermore he's the first Maldivian to accomplish Defence College / War College studies, which is the highest level of military studies attainable. ===Military Decorations=== Maj. General Jaleel is one of the most highly decorated officers, with 10 Service Medals and 9 Service Ribbons for his exemplary leadership and distinguished service in the defence force.{{cite web|url=http://www.miadhu.com/2010/11/local-news/chief-of-defence-force-major-general-moosa-ali-jaleel-awarded-purple-heart-and-long-service-meda|title= Miadhu News (Maldives)|author=|date=2010-11-04|publisher=|accessdate=2010-12-17}} ; Service Medal decorations[http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v3/?page_id=25 ] * The Medal for Exceptional Bravery (Huravee Ran Medal) * The Distinguished Service Medal * The Presidential Medal * The 3 November Medal * The MNDF Service Medal * The Dedicated Service Medal * The Medal of Good Conduct * The Centenary Medal * The Long Service Medal * The Purple Heart Medal (Jihaadhuge Raiy Medal) ; Service Ribbon decorations * Presidential Ribbon * Long Service Ribbon * Dedicated Service Ribbon * MNDF Ribbon * Achievement Ribbon (Twice) * Special Service Ribbon * Good Conduct Ribbon (Twice) ===Badges=== {| class="wikitable" |- |bgcolor="silver" align="center"|Badge ||bgcolor="silver" align="center"|Description |- |[[File:Triangular-dagger-navyred.jpg|75px]] || [[All_Arms_Commando_Course | Royal Marines Commando Badge]] |- |} ===November 3rd 1988 attack=== {{see also|1988 Maldives Coup}} Maj. General Jaleel played a pivotal role in organizing and leading the defence of the NSS HQ during the attack. His military training and knowledge proved to be most valuable to the commanders at the NSS HQ. He received a bullet/shrapnel injury to his leg early on while retaliating to the attacker at the North-East corner of the Bandaara Koshi where the fighting was most intense but even with this injury he continued performing throughout the incident remarkably. His bravery and dedication are most notable as the Commander of the Recce patrol. The Recce patrol was an effort to venture of the NSS HQ which was under siege to retaliate and gather knowledge of the attacker. The first attempt was made to leave the HQ in buses with a tractor leading the way, this effort was aborted after the gate could not be opened as it was jammed due to damage. The second attempt was made through the Defence Ministry gate (then Police HQ gate) on foot. 11 soldiers with task force training volunteered for this mission. After being organized and briefed on the mission by Maj. Gen Jaleel (then Lt.), the patrol was addressed by Maj. Gen (Ret.) Mohamed Zahir (then Major) who was the leading Commander at the NSS HQ at the time. The patrol formed up on the half wall fronting the street then with Maj. Gen Jaleel, the commander at the lead of the patrol, ran out through the gate and along Ameeru Ahmed magu towards Huravee Building. Due to reasons unknown only 9 member were able to run out the gate with 2 members remaining inside. As the attackers noticed the patrol running out of the HQ they intensified the fire towards them and additionally a member of the patrol slipped and was unable to use his weapon to return fire which resulted in 3 member of the patrol being killed under fire. The remaining 6 members completed their mission and returned inside the base through the same gate. The mission is undoubtedly the most daring in the modern military history of the country. The soldiers who volunteered for the mission undertook it with full knowledge that they were venturing out a HQ which was under siege and into the hail of bullets from the attackers. And Maj. Gen Jaleel holds a legendary status in the MNDF as the commander who led this mission. ==Family== Maj. General Jaleel is married to Mrs. Jazeela Ibrahim. He has 5 children, with 1 from the current marriage and 4 from previous marriages. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = [[Mohamed Zahir]]|title =Chief of Defence Force (Maldives)| years = 2008–2012| after = Ahmed Shiyam}} {{s-end}} {{Persondata | NAME = Jaleel, Moosa Ali | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 26 June 1960 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jaleel, Moosa Ali}} [[Category:Maldivian military personnel]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:People from Malé]]

He was the first Maldivian to initiate infantry oriented training in Maldives. He trained a large amount MNDF personnel and also served as the Commanding Officer of the Maldives National Cadet Corp. He enjoys a tremendous amount of public as well as soldiers support and is expected to re-organize and restructure the MNDF as a mission oriented armed force. His experience in various MNDF Units as well as the broad knowledge and wide range of skills makes him a great asset to MNDF and the Maldives. Among his distinctions he's the first Maldivian to complete Officer Cadet training and the only Maldivian graduate of Singapore Armed Forces Officer Cadet School. The only Maldivian to undertake the UK [[Royal Marines]] [[All Arms Commando Course]], as such he's entitled to wear the Commando badge of UK [[Royal Marines]] which is one of the world's most elite fighting forces. Furthermore he's the first Maldivian to accomplish Defence College / War College studies, which is the highest level of military studies attainable. ===Military Decorations=== Maj. General Jaleel is one of the most highly decorated officers, with 10 Service Medals and 9 Service Ribbons for his exemplary leadership and distinguished service in the defence force.{{cite web|url=http://www.miadhu.com/2010/11/local-news/chief-of-defence-force-major-general-moosa-ali-jaleel-awarded-purple-heart-and-long-service-meda|title= Miadhu News (Maldives)|author=|date=2010-11-04|publisher=|accessdate=2010-12-17}} ; Service Medal decorations[http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v3/?page_id=25 ] * The Medal for Exceptional Bravery (Huravee Ran Medal) * The Distinguished Service Medal * The Presidential Medal * The 3 November Medal * The MNDF Service Medal * The Dedicated Service Medal * The Medal of Good Conduct * The Centenary Medal * The Long Service Medal * The Purple Heart Medal (Jihaadhuge Raiy Medal) ; Service Ribbon decorations * Presidential Ribbon * Long Service Ribbon * Dedicated Service Ribbon * MNDF Ribbon * Achievement Ribbon (Twice) * Special Service Ribbon * Good Conduct Ribbon (Twice) ===Badges=== {| class="wikitable" |- |bgcolor="silver" align="center"|Badge ||bgcolor="silver" align="center"|Description |- ||| [[All Arms Commando Course| Royal Marines Commando Badge]] |- |} ===November 3rd 1988 attack=== {{see also|1988 Maldives Coup}} Maj. General Jaleel played a pivotal role in organizing and leading the defence of the NSS HQ during the attack. His military training and knowledge proved to be most valuable to the commanders at the NSS HQ. He received a bullet/shrapnel injury to his leg early on while retaliating to the attacker at the North-East corner of the Bandaara Koshi where the fighting was most intense but even with this injury he continued performing throughout the incident remarkably. His bravery and dedication are most notable as the Commander of the Recce patrol. The Recce patrol was an effort to venture of the NSS HQ which was under siege to retaliate and gather knowledge of the attacker. The first attempt was made to leave the HQ in buses with a tractor leading the way, this effort was aborted after the gate could not be opened as it was jammed due to damage. The second attempt was made through the Defence Ministry gate (then Police HQ gate) on foot. 11 soldiers with task force training volunteered for this mission. After being organized and briefed on the mission by Maj. Gen Jaleel (then Lt.), the patrol was addressed by Maj. Gen (Ret.) Mohamed Zahir (then Major) who was the leading Commander at the NSS HQ at the time. The patrol formed up on the half wall fronting the street then with Maj. Gen Jaleel, the commander at the lead of the patrol, ran out through the gate and along Ameeru Ahmed magu towards Huravee Building. Due to reasons unknown only 9 member were able to run out the gate with 2 members remaining inside. As the attackers noticed the patrol running out of the HQ they intensified the fire towards them and additionally a member of the patrol slipped and was unable to use his weapon to return fire which resulted in 3 member of the patrol being killed under fire. The remaining 6 members completed their mission and returned inside the base through the same gate. The mission is undoubtedly the most daring in the modern military history of the country. The soldiers who volunteered for the mission undertook it with full knowledge that they were venturing out a HQ which was under siege and into the hail of bullets from the attackers. And Maj. Gen Jaleel holds a legendary status in the MNDF as the commander who led this mission. ==Family== Maj. General Jaleel is married to Mrs. Jazeela Ibrahim. He has 5 children, with 1 from the current marriage and 4 from previous marriages. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = [[Mohamed Zahir]]|title =Chief of Defence Force (Maldives)| years = 2008–2012| after = [[Ahmed Shiyam]]}} {{s-end}} {{Persondata | NAME = Jaleel, Moosa Ali | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 26 June 1960 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jaleel, Moosa Ali}} [[Category:Maldivian military personnel]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:People from Malé]]

[[Centenary Medal]]
[[Long Service Medal]]
[[Purple Heart Medal]] (Jihaadhuge Raiy Medal) | laterwork= }} [[Major General]] '''Moosa Ali Jaleel''' RM HRM MSc ndc [[psc]] was the former '''Chief of Defence Force''' of the [[Maldives]] and most senior military officer in the country.http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v1//uploads/op_chart/op_chart.html He is frequently cited as the most highly trained and capable military officer in the country. People who are knowledgeable about [[1988 Maldives Coup|the November 3rd 1988 incident]] and Maj. General Jaleel's bravery and dedicated action that day hold him in the highest regard and respect.{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-V0G78k6jgg|title= Youtube: Moosa Jaleel 3 November Interview|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=}}http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v3/?page_id=17 Maj. General Moosa Jaleel was appointed to the post of '''Chief of Defence Force''' on the 18th November 2008 by the President HE [[Mohamed Nasheed]].http://www.idsa.in/TWIR/11_3_2008_Maldives ==Biography== Maj. General Jaleel was born on 26 June 1960 in [[Malé]], Maldives. He completed his secondary schooling at [[Majeediyya School]]. ===Military Career and Training=== Maj. General Jaleel has the distinction of having been trained at various UK, US and Indian Military Institutes: ; Singapore * [[Officer Cadet School (Singapore)|Officer Cadet School]], [[SAFTI Military Institute|Singapore Armed Forces Training Institute]] (SAFTI) ;United States * [[United States Army Infantry School]], [[Fort Benning]] (Infantry Officer Basic Course / Infantry Officer Advance Course) * Defense Resources Management Institute at [[Naval Postgraduate School]], Monterey California * [[Asia Pacific Center for Security Studies]] (APCSS), Hawaii * [[Near East South Asia Center for Strategic Studies]], Washington DC ;United Kingdom * [[Royal Marines]] Commando School, Lympstone ([[All Arms Commando Course]]) ;India * [[Defence Services Staff College]], Wellington * [[National Defence College]], New Delhi In addition, Maj. General Jaleel holds a Master of Philosophy, M.Phil. and a Master of Science Degree in Defence and Strategic Studies, M.Sc from the [[University of Madras]] India. He also attends the Pacific Armies Management Seminar (PAMS) organized by the [[United States Pacific Command]]. He has commanded all front line infantry units in the MNDF including the '''Rapid Reaction Force''' (RRF), '''Quick Reaction Force III''' (QRF 3), '''Quick Reaction Force I''' (QRF I), '''Special Protection Group''' (SPG) and has also served as the Director General of [[Maldivian Coast Guard]]. He was the first Maldivian to initiate infantry oriented training in Maldives. He trained a large amount MNDF personnel and also served as the Commanding Officer of the Maldives National Cadet Corp. He enjoys a tremendous amount of public as well as soldiers support and is expected to re-organize and restructure the MNDF as a mission oriented armed force. His experience in various MNDF Units as well as the broad knowledge and wide range of skills makes him a great asset to MNDF and the Maldives. Among his distinctions he's the first Maldivian to complete Officer Cadet training and the only Maldivian graduate of Singapore Armed Forces Officer Cadet School. The only Maldivian to undertake the UK [[Royal Marines]] [[All Arms Commando Course]], as such he's entitled to wear the Commando badge of UK [[Royal Marines]] which is one of the world's most elite fighting forces. Furthermore he's the first Maldivian to accomplish Defence College / War College studies, which is the highest level of military studies attainable. ===Military Decorations=== Maj. His military training and knowledge proved to be most valuable to the commanders at the NSS HQ. He received a bullet/shrapnel injury to his leg early on while retaliating to the attacker at the North-East corner of the Bandaara Koshi where the fighting was most intense but even with this injury he continued performing throughout the incident remarkably. He has 5 children, with 1 from the current marriage and 4 from previous marriages. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = [[Mohamed Zahir]]|title =Chief of Defence Force (Maldives)| years = 2008–2012| after = [[Ahmed Shiyam]]}} {{s-end}} {{Persondata | NAME = Jaleel, Moosa Ali | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 26 June 1960 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jaleel, Moosa Ali}} [[Category:Maldivian military personnel]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:People from Malé]]

{{Infobox military person | name = Major General Moosa Ali Jaleel | image=[[File:Jaleel1.jpg|210px|Moosa Ali Jaleel]] | imagesize =210px | birth_date= {{Birth date and age|1960|06|26}} | death_date= | birth_place= | death_place= | placeofburial= | caption= Retired Maj. Gen Jaleel (then Brig.) at the Pacific Armies Management Seminar in Fiji | nickname= Jaleel / CO | allegiance={{flag|Maldives}} | branch=[[Maldives National Defence Force]] | serviceyears= 1980 - 2012 | rank= [[Major General]] | commands=Chief of Defence Force

Commanding Officer - Special Protection Group
Commanding Officer - Maldives National Cadet Corps | unit= | battles=[[1988 Maldives Coup]] | awards=Medal for Exceptional Bravery (Huravee Ran Medal)
Distinguished Service Medal
Presidential Medal
3 November Medal
MNDF Service Medal
Dedicated Service Medal
Medal of Good Conduct
[[Centenary Medal]]
[[Long Service Medal]]
[[Purple Heart Medal]] (Jihaadhuge Raiy Medal) | laterwork= }} [[Major General]] '''Moosa Ali Jaleel''' RM HRM MSc ndc [[psc]] was the former '''Chief of Defence Force''' of the [[Maldives]] and most senior military officer in the country.http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v1//uploads/op_chart/op_chart.html He is frequently cited as the most highly trained and capable military officer in the country. People who are knowledgeable about [[1988 Maldives Coup|the November 3rd 1988 incident]] and Maj. General Jaleel's bravery and dedicated action that day hold him in the highest regard and respect.{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-V0G78k6jgg|title= Youtube: Moosa Jaleel 3 November Interview|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=}}http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v3/?page_id=17 Maj. General Moosa Jaleel was appointed to the post of '''Chief of Defence Force''' on the 18th November 2008 by the President HE [[Mohamed Nasheed]].http://www.idsa.in/TWIR/11_3_2008_Maldives ==Biography== Maj. General Jaleel was born on 26 June 1960 in [[Malé]], Maldives. He completed his secondary schooling at [[Majeediyya School]]. ===Military Career and Training=== Maj. General Jaleel has the distinction of having been trained at various UK, US and Indian Military Institutes: ; Singapore * [[Officer Cadet School (Singapore)|Officer Cadet School]], [[SAFTI Military Institute|Singapore Armed Forces Training Institute]] (SAFTI) ;United States * [[United States Army Infantry School]], [[Fort Benning]] (Infantry Officer Basic Course / Infantry Officer Advance Course) * Defense Resources Management Institute at [[Naval Postgraduate School]], Monterey California * [[Asia Pacific Center for Security Studies]] (APCSS), Hawaii * [[Near East South Asia Center for Strategic Studies]], Washington DC ;United Kingdom * [[Royal Marines]] Commando School, Lympstone ([[All Arms Commando Course]]) ;India * [[Defence Services Staff College]], Wellington * [[National Defence College]], New Delhi In addition, Maj. General Jaleel holds a Master of Philosophy, M.Phil. and a Master of Science Degree in Defence and Strategic Studies, M.Sc from the [[University of Madras]] India. He also attends the Pacific Armies Management Seminar (PAMS) organized by the [[United States Pacific Command]]. He has commanded all front line infantry units in the MNDF including the '''Rapid Reaction Force''' (RRF), '''Quick Reaction Force III''' (QRF 3), '''Quick Reaction Force I''' (QRF I), '''Special Protection Group''' (SPG) and has also served as the Director General of [[Maldivian Coast Guard]]. He was the first Maldivian to initiate infantry oriented training in Maldives. He trained a large amount MNDF personnel and also served as the Commanding Officer of the Maldives National Cadet Corp. He enjoys a tremendous amount of public as well as soldiers support and is expected to re-organize and restructure the MNDF as a mission oriented armed force. His experience in various MNDF Units as well as the broad knowledge and wide range of skills makes him a great asset to MNDF and the Maldives. Among his distinctions he's the first Maldivian to complete Officer Cadet training and the only Maldivian graduate of Singapore Armed Forces Officer Cadet School. The only Maldivian to undertake the UK [[Royal Marines]] [[All Arms Commando Course]], as such he's entitled to wear the Commando badge of UK [[Royal Marines]] which is one of the world's most elite fighting forces. Furthermore he's the first Maldivian to accomplish Defence College / War College studies, which is the highest level of military studies attainable. ===Military Decorations=== Maj. General Jaleel is one of the most highly decorated officers within the [[Maldives National Defence Force]], with 10 Service Medals and 9 Service Ribbons for his exemplary leadership and distinguished service in the defence force.{{cite web|url=http://www.miadhu.com/2010/11/local-news/chief-of-defence-force-major-general-moosa-ali-jaleel-awarded-purple-heart-and-long-service-meda|title= Miadhu News (Maldives)|author=|date=2010-11-04|publisher=|accessdate=2010-12-17}} ; Service Medal decorations[http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v3/?page_id=25 ] * The Presidential Medal * The Defence Force Service Medal * The Distinguished Service Medal * The Good Conduct Medal * The Medal for Exceptional Bravery (Huravee Ran Medal) * The Dedicated Service Medal * The Purple Heart (Jihaadhuge Raiy Medal) * The Long Service Medal * The 3rd November Medal * The Centenary Medal ; Service Ribbon decorations * Presidential Ribbon * Defence Force Service Ribbon * Long Service Ribbon * Dedicated Service Ribbon * Special Duty Ribbon * Achievement Ribbon (Twice) * Good Conduct Ribbon (Twice) ===Badges=== {| class="wikitable" |- |bgcolor="silver" align="center"|Badge ||bgcolor="silver" align="center"|Description |- ||| [[All Arms Commando Course| Royal Marines Commando Badge]] |- |} ===November 3rd 1988 attack=== {{see also|1988 Maldives Coup}} Maj. General Jaleel played a pivotal role in organizing and leading the defence of the NSS HQ during the attack. His military training and knowledge proved to be most valuable to the commanders at the NSS HQ. He received a bullet/shrapnel injury to his leg early on while retaliating to the attacker at the North-East corner of the Bandaara Koshi where the fighting was most intense but even with this injury he continued performing throughout the incident remarkably. His bravery and dedication are most notable as the Commander of the Recce patrol. The Recce patrol was an effort to venture of the NSS HQ which was under siege to retaliate and gather knowledge of the attacker. The first attempt was made to leave the HQ in buses with a tractor leading the way, this effort was aborted after the gate could not be opened as it was jammed due to damage. The second attempt was made through the Defence Ministry gate (then Police HQ gate) on foot. 11 soldiers with task force training volunteered for this mission. After being organized and briefed on the mission by Maj. Gen Jaleel (then Lt.), the patrol was addressed by Maj. Gen (Ret.) Mohamed Zahir (then Major) who was the leading Commander at the NSS HQ at the time. The patrol formed up on the half wall fronting the street then with Maj. Gen Jaleel, the commander at the lead of the patrol, ran out through the gate and along Ameeru Ahmed magu towards Huravee Building. Due to reasons unknown only 9 member were able to run out the gate with 2 members remaining inside. As the attackers noticed the patrol running out of the HQ they intensified the fire towards them and additionally a member of the patrol slipped and was unable to use his weapon to return fire which resulted in 3 member of the patrol being killed under fire. The remaining 6 members completed their mission and returned inside the base through the same gate. The mission is undoubtedly the most daring in the modern military history of the country. The soldiers who volunteered for the mission undertook it with full knowledge that they were venturing out a HQ which was under siege and into the hail of bullets from the attackers. And Maj. Gen Jaleel holds a legendary status in the MNDF as the commander who led this mission. ==Family== Maj. General Jaleel is married to Mrs. Jazeela Ibrahim. He has 5 children, with 1 from the current marriage and 4 from previous marriages. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = [[Mohamed Zahir]]|title =Chief of Defence Force (Maldives)| years = 2008–2012| after = [[Ahmed Shiyam]]}} {{s-end}} {{Persondata | NAME = Jaleel, Moosa Ali | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 26 June 1960 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jaleel, Moosa Ali}} [[Category:Maldivian military personnel]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:People from Malé]]

He was the first Maldivian to initiate infantry oriented training in Maldives. He trained a large amount MNDF personnel and also served as the Commanding Officer of the Maldives National Cadet Corp. ==Military Career and Training== Maj. General Jaleel has the distinction of having been trained at various UK, US and Indian Military Institutes: ; Singapore * [[Officer Cadet School (Singapore)|Officer Cadet School]], [[SAFTI Military Institute|Singapore Armed Forces Training Institute]] (SAFTI) ;United States * [[United States Army Infantry School]], [[Fort Benning]] (Infantry Officer Basic Course / Infantry Officer Advance Course) * Defense Resources Management Institute at [[Naval Postgraduate School]], Monterey California * [[Asia Pacific Center for Security Studies]] (APCSS), Hawaii * [[Near East South Asia Center for Strategic Studies]], Washington DC ;United Kingdom * [[Royal Marines]] Commando School, Lympstone ([[All Arms Commando Course]]) ;India * [[Defence Services Staff College]], Wellington * [[National Defence College]], New Delhi In addition, Maj. General Jaleel holds a Master of Philosophy, M.Phil. and a Master of Science Degree in Defence and Strategic Studies, M.Sc from the [[University of Madras]] India. He also attends the Pacific Armies Management Seminar (PAMS) organized by the [[United States Pacific Command]]. Among his distinctions he's the first Maldivian to complete Officer Cadet training and the only Maldivian graduate of Singapore Armed Forces Officer Cadet School. The only Maldivian to undertake the UK [[Royal Marines]] [[All Arms Commando Course]], as such he's entitled to wear the Commando badge of UK [[Royal Marines]] which is one of the world's most elite fighting forces. Furthermore he's the first Maldivian to accomplish Defence College / War College studies, which is the highest level of military studies attainable. ==Military Decorations== Maj. General Jaleel is one of the most highly decorated officers within the [[Maldives National Defence Force]], with 10 Service Medals and 9 Service Ribbons for his exemplary leadership and distinguished service in the defence force.{{cite web|url=http://www.miadhu.com/2010/11/local-news/chief-of-defence-force-major-general-moosa-ali-jaleel-awarded-purple-heart-and-long-service-meda|title= Miadhu News (Maldives)|author=|date=2010-11-04|publisher=|accessdate=2010-12-17}} Major General Moosa Ali Jaleel was awarded Purple Heart for being wounded in the field in the battle against the coup attempt on 3 November 1988 by mercenaries linked to a Sri Lankan terrorist group. Long Service Medal was awarded to Major General Jaleel in recognition of his 30 year of distinguished service to the Maldives military. ; Service Medal decorations[http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v3/?page_id=25 ] * The Presidential Medal * The Defence Force Service Medal * The Distinguished Service Medal * The Good Conduct Medal * The Medal for Exceptional Bravery (Huravee Ran Medal) * The Dedicated Service Medal * The Purple Heart (Jihaadhuge Raiy Medal) * The Long Service Medal * The 3rd November Medal * The Centenary Medal ; Service Ribbon decorations * Presidential Ribbon * Defence Force Service Ribbon * Long Service Ribbon * Dedicated Service Ribbon * Special Duty Ribbon * Achievement Ribbon (Twice) * Good Conduct Ribbon (Twice) ; Overseas decorations * [[All Arms Commando Course| Royal Marines Commando Badge]] ==November 3rd 1988 attack== {{see also|1988 Maldives Coup}} Maj. General Jaleel played a pivotal role in organizing and leading the defence of the NSS HQ during the attack. His military training and knowledge proved to be most valuable to the commanders at the NSS HQ. He received a bullet/shrapnel injury to his leg early on while retaliating to the attacker at the North-East corner of the Bandaara Koshi where the fighting was most intense but even with this injury he continued performing throughout the incident remarkably. His bravery and dedication are most notable as the Commander of the Recce patrol. The Recce patrol was an effort to venture of the NSS HQ which was under siege to retaliate and gather knowledge of the attacker. The first attempt was made to leave the HQ in buses with a tractor leading the way, this effort was aborted after the gate could not be opened as it was jammed due to damage. The second attempt was made through the Defence Ministry gate (then Police HQ gate) on foot. 11 soldiers with task force training volunteered for this mission. After being organized and briefed on the mission by Maj. Gen Jaleel (then Lt.), the patrol was addressed by Maj. Gen (Ret.) Mohamed Zahir (then Major) who was the leading Commander at the NSS HQ at the time. The patrol formed up on the half wall fronting the street then with Maj. Gen Jaleel, the commander at the lead of the patrol, ran out through the gate and along Ameeru Ahmed magu towards Huravee Building. Due to reasons unknown only 9 member were able to run out the gate with 2 members remaining inside. As the attackers noticed the patrol running out of the HQ they intensified the fire towards them and additionally a member of the patrol slipped and was unable to use his weapon to return fire which resulted in 3 member of the patrol being killed under fire. The remaining 6 members completed their mission and returned inside the base through the same gate. The mission is undoubtedly the most daring in the modern military history of the country. The soldiers who volunteered for the mission undertook it with full knowledge that they were venturing out a HQ which was under siege and into the hail of bullets from the attackers. And Maj. Gen Jaleel holds a legendary status in the MNDF as the commander who led this mission. ==Family== Maj. General Jaleel is married to Mrs. Jazeela Ibrahim. He has 5 children, with 1 from the current marriage and 4 from previous marriages. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = [[Mohamed Zahir]]|title =Chief of Defence Force (Maldives)| years = 2008–2012| after = [[Ahmed Shiyam]]}} {{s-end}} {{Persondata | NAME = Jaleel, Moosa Ali | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 26 June 1960 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jaleel, Moosa Ali}} [[Category:Maldivian military personnel]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:People from Malé]]

| laterwork= }} [[Major General]] (Retired) '''Moosa Ali Jaleel''' RM HRM MSc [[National Defence College, India|ndc]] [[psc (British Army)|psc]] was the former '''Chief of Defence Force''' of the [[Maldives National Defence Force]] and most senior military officer in the country at his time.http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v1//uploads/op_chart/op_chart.html ==Biography== Maj. General Jaleel's bravery and dedicated action that day hold him in the highest regard and respect.{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-V0G78k6jgg|title= Youtube: Moosa Jaleel 3 November Interview|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=}}http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v3/?page_id=17 He enjoys a tremendous amount of public as well as soldiers support and during his leadership, he enormously contributed to develop the human resources and infrastructure of MNDF and re-organize and restructure the MNDF as a mission oriented armed force. Gen) at the Pacific Armies Management Seminar in Fiji | birth_date= {{Birth date and age|1960|06|26}} | death_date= | birth_place= | death_place= | placeofburial= | nickname= Jaleel / CO | allegiance=[[Maldives]] | branch=[[Maldives National Defence Force]] | serviceyears= 1980 - 2012 | rank= [[Major General]] | commands= {{plainlist| *Chief of Defence Force *Vice Chief of Defence Force *Commanding General - Rapid Reaction Force *Director General - Coast Guard *Commanding Officer - Quick Reaction Force I & II & III *Commanding Officer - Special Protection Group *Commanding Officer - Maldives National Cadet Corps }} | unit= | battles=[[1988 Maldives Coup]] | awards= {{plainlist| *Medal for Exceptional Bravery *Distinguished Service Medal *Presidential Medal *3rd November Medal *Defence Force Service Medal *Dedicated Service Medal *Good Conduct Medal *Centenary Medal *Long Service Medal *Purple Heart }} | laterwork= }}
[[Major General]] (Retired) '''Moosa Ali Jaleel''' RM HRM MSc [[National Defence College, India|ndc]] [[psc (British Army)|psc]] was the former '''Chief of Defence Force''' of the [[Maldives National Defence Force]] and most senior military officer in the country at his time.<ref>http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v1//uploads/op_chart/op_chart.html</ref>
<!-- Unsourced image removed: [[Image:Jaleelpromote.jpg|thumb|right|210px|The President presenting the letter of promotion to the rank of Brigadier, to Colonel Moosa Ali Jaleel on 21 April 2004]] -->
==Biography== Maj. General Jaleel was born on 26 June 1960 in [[Malé]], Maldives. He completed his secondary schooling at [[Majeediyya School]].
He is frequently cited as the most highly trained and capable military officer in the country. People who are knowledgeable about [[1988 Maldives Coup|the November 3rd 1988 incident]] and Maj. General Jaleel's bravery and dedicated action that day hold him in the highest regard and respect.<ref name="3rd November 1988 ">{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-V0G78k6jgg|title= Youtube: Moosa Jaleel 3 November Interview|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v3/?page_id=17</ref>
He enjoys a tremendous amount of public as well as soldiers support and during his leadership, he enormously contributed to develop the human resources and infrastructure of MNDF and re-organize and restructure the MNDF as a mission oriented armed force. His experience in various MNDF Units as well as the broad knowledge and wide range of skills makes him a great asset to MNDF and the Maldives.
He has commanded all front line infantry units in the MNDF including the '''Rapid Reaction Force''' (RRF), '''Quick Reaction Force III''' (QRF 3), '''Quick Reaction Force I''' (QRF I), '''Special Protection Group''' (SPG) and has also served as the Director General of [[Maldivian Coast Guard]]. He was the first Maldivian to initiate infantry oriented training in Maldives. He trained a large amount MNDF personnel and also served as the Commanding Officer of the Maldives National Cadet Corp.
Maj. General Moosa Jaleel was appointed to the post of '''Chief of Defence Force''' on the 18th November 2008 by the President HE [[Mohamed Nasheed]].<ref>http://www.idsa.in/TWIR/11_3_2008_Maldives</ref> He honorably retired from active service on 8th february 2012. On officially accepting his retirement, HE [[Dr. Mohamed Waheed Hassan Manik]] thanked the Chief of Defence Force for his dedicated service to the nation as an MNDF officer.
==Military Career and Training== Maj. General Jaleel has the distinction of having been trained at various UK, US and Indian Military Institutes:
; Singapore * [[Officer Cadet School (Singapore)|Officer Cadet School]], [[SAFTI Military Institute|Singapore Armed Forces Training Institute]] (SAFTI)
;United States * [[United States Army Infantry School]], [[Fort Benning]] (Infantry Officer Basic Course / Infantry Officer Advance Course) * Defense Resources Management Institute at [[Naval Postgraduate School]], Monterey California * [[Asia Pacific Center for Security Studies]] (APCSS), Hawaii * [[Near East South Asia Center for Strategic Studies]], Washington DC
;United Kingdom * [[Royal Marines]] Commando School, Lympstone ([[All Arms Commando Course]])
;India * [[Defence Services Staff College]], Wellington * [[National Defence College]], New Delhi
<!-- Commented out because image was deleted: [[Image:mjaleel2.jpg|thumb|right|250px|USS Cleveland's commanding officer Capt.Billy Hart, presents a plaque to the Brigadier during the visit to amphibious transport dock USS Cleveland, on Dec.18 during a joint training exercise with the MNDF QRF]] -->
In addition, Maj. General Jaleel holds a Master of Philosophy, M.Phil. and a Master of Science Degree in Defence and Strategic Studies, M.Sc from the [[University of Madras]] India. He also attends the Pacific Armies Management Seminar (PAMS) organized by the [[United States Pacific Command]].
Among his distinctions he's the first Maldivian to complete Officer Cadet training and the only Maldivian graduate of Singapore Armed Forces Officer Cadet School. The only Maldivian to undertake the UK [[Royal Marines]] [[All Arms Commando Course]], as such he's entitled to wear the Commando badge of UK [[Royal Marines]] which is one of the world's most elite fighting forces. Furthermore he's the first Maldivian to accomplish Defence College / War College studies, which is the highest level of military studies attainable.
==Military Decorations== Maj. General Jaleel is one of the most highly decorated officers within the [[Maldives National Defence Force]], with 10 Service Medals and 9 Service Ribbons for his exemplary leadership and distinguished service in the defence force.<ref name="Medals">{{cite web|url=http://www.miadhu.com/2010/11/local-news/chief-of-defence-force-major-general-moosa-ali-jaleel-awarded-purple-heart-and-long-service-meda|title= Miadhu News (Maldives)|author=|date=2010-11-04|publisher=|accessdate=2010-12-17}}</ref> Major General Moosa Ali Jaleel was awarded Purple Heart for being wounded in the field in the battle against the coup attempt on 3 November 1988 by mercenaries linked to a Sri Lankan terrorist group. Long Service Medal was awarded to Major General Jaleel in recognition of his 30 year of distinguished service to the Maldives military.
; Service Medal decorations<ref name="MNDF Medals">[http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v3/?page_id=25 ]</ref> * The Presidential Medal * The Defence Force Service Medal * The Distinguished Service Medal * The Good Conduct Medal * The Medal for Exceptional Bravery (Huravee Ran Medal) * The Dedicated Service Medal * The Purple Heart (Jihaadhuge Raiy Medal) * The Long Service Medal * The 3rd November Medal * The Centenary Medal
; Service Ribbon decorations<ref name="MNDF Medals" /> * Presidential Ribbon * Defence Force Service Ribbon * Long Service Ribbon * Dedicated Service Ribbon * Special Duty Ribbon * Achievement Ribbon (Twice) * Good Conduct Ribbon (Twice)
; Overseas decorations * [[All Arms Commando Course| Royal Marines Commando Badge]]
==November 3rd 1988 attack== {{see also|1988 Maldives Coup}}
Maj. General Jaleel played a pivotal role in organizing and leading the defence of the NSS HQ during the attack. His military training and knowledge proved to be most valuable to the commanders at the NSS HQ. He received a bullet/shrapnel injury to his leg early on while retaliating to the attacker at the North-East corner of the Bandaara Koshi where the fighting was most intense but even with this injury he continued performing throughout the incident remarkably.<ref name="3rd November 1988 "/>
His bravery and dedication are most notable as the Commander of the Recce patrol. The Recce patrol was an effort to venture of the NSS HQ which was under siege to retaliate and gather knowledge of the attacker. The first attempt was made to leave the HQ in buses with a tractor leading the way, this effort was aborted after the gate could not be opened as it was jammed due to damage. The second attempt was made through the Defence Ministry gate (then Police HQ gate) on foot. 11 soldiers with task force training volunteered for this mission. After being organized and briefed on the mission by Maj. Gen Jaleel (then Lt.), the patrol was addressed by Maj. Gen (Ret.) Mohamed Zahir (then Major) who was the leading Commander at the NSS HQ at the time.<ref name="3rd November 1988 "/>
The patrol formed up on the half wall fronting the street then with Maj. Gen Jaleel, the commander at the lead of the patrol, ran out through the gate and along Ameeru Ahmed magu towards Huravee Building. Due to reasons unknown only 9 member were able to run out the gate with 2 members remaining inside. As the attackers noticed the patrol running out of the HQ they intensified the fire towards them and additionally a member of the patrol slipped and was unable to use his weapon to return fire which resulted in 3 member of the patrol being killed under fire. The remaining 6 members completed their mission and returned inside the base through the same gate.<ref name="3rd November 1988 "/>
The mission is undoubtedly the most daring in the modern military history of the country. The soldiers who volunteered for the mission undertook it with full knowledge that they were venturing out a HQ which was under siege and into the hail of bullets from the attackers. And Maj. Gen Jaleel holds a legendary status in the MNDF as the commander who led this mission.<ref name="3rd November 1988 "/>
==Family== Maj. General Jaleel is married to Mrs. Jazeela Ibrahim. He has 5 children, with 1 from the current marriage and 4 from previous marriages.

Furthermore he's the first Maldivian to accomplish Defence College / War College studies, which is the highest level of military studies attainable.
==Military Decorations== Maj. General Jaleel is one of the most highly decorated officers within the [[Maldives National Defence Force]], with 10 Service Medals and 9 Service Ribbons for his exemplary leadership and distinguished service in the defence force.<ref name="Medals">{{cite web|url=http://www.miadhu.com/2010/11/local-news/chief-of-defence-force-major-general-moosa-ali-jaleel-awarded-purple-heart-and-long-service-meda|title= Miadhu News (Maldives)|author=|date=2010-11-04|publisher=|accessdate=2010-12-17}}</ref> Major General Moosa Ali Jaleel was awarded Purple Heart for being wounded in the field in the battle against the coup attempt on 3 November 1988 by mercenaries linked to a Sri Lankan terrorist group. Long Service Medal was awarded to Major General Jaleel in recognition of his 30 year of distinguished service to the Maldives military.
; Service Medal decorations<ref name="MNDF Medals">[http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v3/?page_id=25 ]</ref> * The Presidential Medal * The Defence Force Service Medal * The Distinguished Service Medal * The Good Conduct Medal * The Medal for Exceptional Bravery (Huravee Ran Medal) * The Dedicated Service Medal * The Purple Heart (Jihaadhuge Raiy Medal) * The Long Service Medal * The 3rd November Medal * The Centenary Medal
; Service Ribbon decorations<ref name="MNDF Medals" /> * Presidential Ribbon * Defence Force Service Ribbon * Long Service Ribbon * Dedicated Service Ribbon * Special Duty Ribbon * Achievement Ribbon (Twice) * Good Conduct Ribbon (Twice)
; Overseas decorations * [[All Arms Commando Course| Royal Marines Commando Badge]]
==November 3rd 1988 attack== {{see also|1988 Maldives Coup}}
Maj. General Jaleel played a pivotal role in organizing and leading the defence of the NSS HQ during the attack. His military training and knowledge proved to be most valuable to the commanders at the NSS HQ. He received a bullet/shrapnel injury to his leg early on while retaliating to the attacker at the North-East corner of the Bandaara Koshi where the fighting was most intense but even with this injury he continued performing throughout the incident remarkably.<ref name="3rd November 1988 "/>
His bravery and dedication are most notable as the Commander of the Recce patrol. The Recce patrol was an effort to venture of the NSS HQ which was under siege to retaliate and gather knowledge of the attacker. The first attempt was made to leave the HQ in buses with a tractor leading the way, this effort was aborted after the gate could not be opened as it was jammed due to damage. The second attempt was made through the Defence Ministry gate (then Police HQ gate) on foot. 11 soldiers with task force training volunteered for this mission. After being organized and briefed on the mission by Maj. Gen Jaleel (then Lt.), the patrol was addressed by Maj. Gen (Ret.) Mohamed Zahir (then Major) who was the leading Commander at the NSS HQ at the time.<ref name="3rd November 1988 "/>
The patrol formed up on the half wall fronting the street then with Maj. Gen Jaleel, the commander at the lead of the patrol, ran out through the gate and along Ameeru Ahmed magu towards Huravee Building. Due to reasons unknown only 9 member were able to run out the gate with 2 members remaining inside. As the attackers noticed the patrol running out of the HQ they intensified the fire towards them and additionally a member of the patrol slipped and was unable to use his weapon to return fire which resulted in 3 member of the patrol being killed under fire. The remaining 6 members completed their mission and returned inside the base through the same gate.<ref name="3rd November 1988 "/>
The mission is undoubtedly the most daring in the modern military history of the country. The soldiers who volunteered for the mission undertook it with full knowledge that they were venturing out a HQ which was under siege and into the hail of bullets from the attackers. And Maj. Gen Jaleel holds a legendary status in the MNDF as the commander who led this mission.<ref name="3rd November 1988 "/>
==Family== Maj. General Jaleel is married to Mrs. Jazeela Ibrahim. He has 5 children, with 1 from the current marriage and 4 from previous marriages.
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox military person | name = Major General Moosa Ali Jaleel | image= Jaleel1.jpg | image_size = 210 | caption= Retired Maj. Gen Jaleel (then Brig. Gen) at the Pacific Armies Management Seminar in Fiji | birth_date= {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1960|06|26}} | death_date= | birth_place= | death_place= | placeofburial= | nickname= Jaleel / CO | allegiance=[[Maldives]] | branch=[[Maldives National Defence Force]] | serviceyears= 1980 - 2012 | rank= [[Major General]] | commands= {{plainlist| *Chief of Defence Force *Vice Chief of Defence Force *Commanding General - Rapid Reaction Force *Director General - Coast Guard *Commanding Officer - Quick Reaction Force I & II & III *Commanding Officer - Special Protection Group *Commanding Officer - Maldives National Cadet Corps }} | unit= | battles=[[1988 Maldives Coup]] | awards= {{plainlist| *Medal for Exceptional Bravery *Distinguished Service Medal *Presidential Medal *3 November Medal *Defence Force Service Medal *Dedicated Service Medal *Good Conduct Medal *Centenary Medal *Long Service Medal *Purple Heart }} | laterwork= }}
[[Major General]] (Retired) '''Moosa Ali Jaleel''' RM HRM MSc [[National Defence College, India|ndc]] [[psc (British Army)|psc]] was the former '''Chief of Defence Force''' of the [[Maldives National Defence Force]] and most senior military officer in the country at his time.<ref>http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v1//uploads/op_chart/op_chart.html</ref>
<!-- Unsourced image removed: [[File:Jaleelpromote.jpg|thumb|right|210px|The President presenting the letter of promotion to the rank of Brigadier, to Colonel Moosa Ali Jaleel on 21 April 2004]] -->
==Biography== Maj. General Jaleel was born on 26 June 1960 in [[Malé]], Maldives. He completed his secondary schooling at [[Majeediyya School]].
He is frequently cited as the most highly trained and capable military officer in the country. People who are knowledgeable about [[1988 Maldives Coup|the November 3rd 1988 incident]] and Maj. General Jaleel's bravery and dedicated action that day hold him in the highest regard and respect.<ref name="3rd November 1988 ">{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-V0G78k6jgg|title= Youtube: Moosa Jaleel 3 November Interview|author=|date=|publisher=|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v3/?page_id=17</ref>
He enjoys a tremendous amount of public as well as soldiers support and during his leadership, he enormously contributed to develop the human resources and infrastructure of MNDF and re-organize and restructure the MNDF as a mission oriented armed force. His experience in various MNDF Units as well as the broad knowledge and wide range of skills makes him a great asset to MNDF and the Maldives.
He has commanded all front line infantry units in the MNDF including the '''Rapid Reaction Force''' (RRF), '''Quick Reaction Force III''' (QRF 3), '''Quick Reaction Force I''' (QRF I), '''Special Protection Group''' (SPG) and has also served as the Director General of [[Maldivian Coast Guard]]. He was the first Maldivian to initiate infantry oriented training in Maldives. He trained a large amount MNDF personnel and also served as the Commanding Officer of the Maldives National Cadet Corp.
Maj. General Moosa Jaleel was appointed to the post of '''Chief of Defence Force''' on 18 November 2008 by the President HE [[Mohamed Nasheed]].<ref>http://www.idsa.in/TWIR/11_3_2008_Maldives</ref> He honorably retired from active service on 8 February 2012. On officially accepting his retirement, HE [[Dr. Mohamed Waheed Hassan Manik]] thanked the Chief of Defence Force for his dedicated service to the nation as an MNDF officer.
==Military Career and Training== Maj. General Jaleel has the distinction of having been trained at various UK, US and Indian Military Institutes:
; Singapore * [[Officer Cadet School (Singapore)|Officer Cadet School]], [[SAFTI Military Institute|Singapore Armed Forces Training Institute]] (SAFTI)
;United States * [[United States Army Infantry School]], [[Fort Benning]] (Infantry Officer Basic Course / Infantry Officer Advance Course) * Defense Resources Management Institute at [[Naval Postgraduate School]], Monterey California * [[Asia Pacific Center for Security Studies]] (APCSS), Hawaii * [[Near East South Asia Center for Strategic Studies]], Washington DC
;United Kingdom * [[Royal Marines]] Commando School, Lympstone ([[All Arms Commando Course]])
;India * [[Defence Services Staff College]], Wellington * [[National Defence College, India|National Defence College]], New Delhi
<!-- Commented out because image was deleted: [[File:mjaleel2.jpg|thumb|right|250px|USS Cleveland's commanding officer Capt.Billy Hart, presents a plaque to the Brigadier during the visit to amphibious transport dock USS Cleveland, on Dec.18 during a joint training exercise with the MNDF QRF]] -->
In addition, Maj. General Jaleel holds a Master of Philosophy, M.Phil. and a Master of Science Degree in Defence and Strategic Studies, M.Sc from the [[University of Madras]] India. He also attends the Pacific Armies Management Seminar (PAMS) organized by the [[United States Pacific Command]].
Among his distinctions he's the first Maldivian to complete Officer Cadet training and the only Maldivian graduate of Singapore Armed Forces Officer Cadet School. The only Maldivian to undertake the UK [[Royal Marines]] [[All Arms Commando Course]], as such he's entitled to wear the Commando badge of UK [[Royal Marines]] which is one of the world's most elite fighting forces. Furthermore he's the first Maldivian to accomplish Defence College / War College studies, which is the highest level of military studies attainable.
==Military Decorations== Maj. General Jaleel is one of the most highly decorated officers within the [[Maldives National Defence Force]], with 10 Service Medals and 9 Service Ribbons for his exemplary leadership and distinguished service in the defence force.<ref name="Medals">{{cite web|url=http://www.miadhu.com/2010/11/local-news/chief-of-defence-force-major-general-moosa-ali-jaleel-awarded-purple-heart-and-long-service-meda|title= Miadhu News (Maldives)|author=|date=2010-11-04|publisher=|accessdate=2010-12-17}}</ref> Major General Moosa Ali Jaleel was awarded Purple Heart for being wounded in the field in the battle against the coup attempt on 3 November 1988 by mercenaries linked to a Sri Lankan terrorist group. Long Service Medal was awarded to Major General Jaleel in recognition of his 30 year of distinguished service to the Maldives military.
; Service Medal decorations<ref name="MNDF Medals">[http://www.mndf.gov.mv/v3/?page_id=25 ]</ref> * The Presidential Medal * The Defence Force Service Medal * The Distinguished Service Medal * The Good Conduct Medal * The Medal for Exceptional Bravery (Huravee Ran Medal) * The Dedicated Service Medal * The Purple Heart (Jihaadhuge Raiy Medal) * The Long Service Medal * The 3 November Medal * The Centenary Medal
; Service Ribbon decorations<ref name="MNDF Medals" /> * Presidential Ribbon * Defence Force Service Ribbon * Long Service Ribbon * Dedicated Service Ribbon * Special Duty Ribbon * Achievement Ribbon (Twice) * Good Conduct Ribbon (Twice)
; Overseas decorations * [[All Arms Commando Course| Royal Marines Commando Badge]]
==3 November 1988 attack== {{see also|1988 Maldives Coup}}
Maj. General Jaleel played a pivotal role in organizing and leading the defence of the NSS HQ during the attack. His military training and knowledge proved to be most valuable to the commanders at the NSS HQ. He received a bullet/shrapnel injury to his leg early on while retaliating to the attacker at the North-East corner of the Bandaara Koshi where the fighting was most intense but even with this injury he continued performing throughout the incident remarkably.<ref name="3rd November 1988 "/>
His bravery and dedication are most notable as the Commander of the Recce patrol. The Recce patrol was an effort to venture of the NSS HQ which was under siege to retaliate and gather knowledge of the attacker. The first attempt was made to leave the HQ in buses with a tractor leading the way, this effort was aborted after the gate could not be opened as it was jammed due to damage. The second attempt was made through the Defence Ministry gate (then Police HQ gate) on foot. 11 soldiers with task force training volunteered for this mission. After being organized and briefed on the mission by Maj. Gen Jaleel (then Lt.), the patrol was addressed by Maj. Gen (Ret.) Mohamed Zahir (then Major) who was the leading Commander at the NSS HQ at the time.<ref name="3rd November 1988 "/>
The patrol formed up on the half wall fronting the street then with Maj. Gen Jaleel, the commander at the lead of the patrol, ran out through the gate and along Ameeru Ahmed magu towards Huravee Building. Due to reasons unknown only 9 member were able to run out the gate with 2 members remaining inside. As the attackers noticed the patrol running out of the HQ they intensified the fire towards them and additionally a member of the patrol slipped and was unable to use his weapon to return fire which resulted in 3 member of the patrol being killed under fire. The remaining 6 members completed their mission and returned inside the base through the same gate.<ref name="3rd November 1988 "/>
The mission is undoubtedly the most daring in the modern military history of the country. The soldiers who volunteered for the mission undertook it with full knowledge that they were venturing out a HQ which was under siege and into the hail of bullets from the attackers. And Maj. Gen Jaleel holds a legendary status in the MNDF as the commander who led this mission.<ref name="3rd November 1988 "/>
